title: Feature Guided Search for Creative Problem Solving Through Tool Construction
explanation: Part of a very fun project on "MacGyvering" with a robot (https://ece.gatech.edu/news/2023/12/formula-creativity).

title: Qualitative Simulation
explanation: This is a classic -- anyone thinking about robots/agents that reason and plan at multiple levels of abstraction, especially in physical systems, will enjoy.

title: Using Source Code to Solve Control Problems
explanation: If an agent has a programmatic world model, it should use that structure to make better and faster decisions.

title: Language and Culture Internalisation for Human-Like Autotelic AI
explanation: Makes a very interesting case for social interaction and culture as major drivers for the emergence of intelligent agents.

title: Learning with 3D Rotations, a Hitchhiker's Guide to SO(3)
explanation: This is quickly becoming one of the papers I most often share. Useful, systematic, and nicely written.

title: Robots for Humanity: In-Home Deployment of Stretch RE2
explanation: This is probably the most inspiring robot video/demo that I've ever seen: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K2U7wwEMLDU

title: AdaptSim: Task-Driven Simulation Adaptation for Sim-to-Real Transfer
explanation: Simulators need not be realistic---they just need to be useful for downstream decision-making!

title: A Survey on Hierarchical Planning â€“ One Abstract Idea, Many Concrete Realizations
explanation: This has the best short intro to Hierarchical Task Networks and related formalisms that I have seen.

title: REPeat: A Real2Sim2Real Approach for Pre-acquisition of Soft Food Items in Robot-assisted Feeding
explanation: This is the kind of rich, messy manipulation & planning that our robots need.

title: Uncertainty Quantification for Neurosymbolic Programs via Compositional Conformal Prediction
explanation: Very creative synthesis of ideas. I would love to see applications to robot planning.

title: Learning Sequential Acquisition Policies for Robot-Assisted Feeding
explanation: I really admire this: it's cool from a general AI/robotics perspective *and* focused on an important application.

title: Bayesian Policy Search with Policy Priors
explanation: If "learning to learn", "planning as inference", or "hierarchical Bayesian" gets your attention, you'll enjoy this paper. Also, #SnakesOnAPlane.

title: Planning for Learning Object Properties
explanation: A very nice instance of using planning to learn (to get better at planning). Real robot results too!

title: Towards a Unified Theory of State Abstraction for MDPs
explanation: This is my go-to reference for state abstractions. Table 1 is especially helpful.

title: Semantically Grounded Learning from Unstructured Demonstrations
explanation: A must-read if you're thinking about developing robots that learn (and generalize!) from demonstrations.

title: Learning to Rank for Synthesizing Planning Heuristics
explanation: Heuristics are estimated costs-to-go, so we should train them that way, right? Not necessarily!

title: Learning Inadmissible Heuristics During Search
explanation: It's cool and surprising that we can learn to get better at search, during search itself, before even finding a solution.

title: Learning Tasks From A Single Demonstration
explanation: A title ahead of its time! My favorite part, though, is the thorough & thoughtful discussion section.

title: CORN: Contact-based Object Representation for Nonprehensile Manipulation of General Unseen Objects
explanation: The real nonprehensile manipulation videos are pretty remarkable.

title: Inductive Logic Programming At 30: A New Introduction
explanation: When I first started reading about ILP, I really wanted an explanation in modern ML terms. This does that & a lot more!

title: Learning by Analogy: Formulating and Generalizing Plans from Past Experience
explanation: Ambitious and ahead of its time. Analogical reasoning is under-utilized in modern AI, imo.

title: Discovery of Complex Behaviors through Contact-Invariant Optimization
explanation: The behaviors synthesized are still among the coolest I've ever seen. An elegant idea, too.

title: Learning Symbolic Models of Stochastic Domains
explanation: This was hugely influential in my PhD. The scope is incredible (you think they're done; then they add concept learning!)

title: Finding Options that Minimize Planning Time
explanation: This paper has a unique & compelling answer to the question: how should we discover high-level action abstractions (and why)?

title: Pengi: An Implementation of a Theory of Activity
explanation: This paper points to a kind of improvisational decision-making that I still don't think we've figured out. Also has a great critique of planning.
